title: How to Ask if a Job Is Still Open

steps.title: Reach out to HR or a hiring manager.
steps.content: Reach out to HR or a hiring manager. They’re the ones who will be able to tell you whether or not the job is still open. Try checking the company’s website to see if they have any contact information for their recruiters, too. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Ask questions about the job.
steps.content: Ask questions about the job. Once you get ahold of someone, start out by asking if the job is still available. If it is, treat the phone call like a pre-interview: ask about the position, what it entails, and who they’re looking for. Always be polite, and try not to take up too much of their time if they sound busy. [2] X Research source Try to act humble throughout the phone conversation. This could be a good way to score points with the director or manager. [3] X Expert Source Lucy Yeh Career & Life Coach Expert Interview. 21 November 2019.

steps.title: Thank the person for their time.
steps.content: Thank the person for their time. At the end of the phone call, thank the person for being so helpful and remind them of your name. Let them know that you’ll be submitting an application later that day so they can watch out for your resumé. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Yes, if you haven’t heard anything in about a week.
steps.content: Yes, if you haven’t heard anything in about a week. It will show the company that you’re serious about wanting the position. It also tells your potential employer that you’re responsible and dedicated, just like you would be on the job. [5] X Research source Try to check in with the person who arranged the interview. [6] X Expert Source Lucy Yeh Career & Life Coach Expert Interview. 21 November 2019. If you were referred to the job opening by someone within the company, you could check in with them to see if they have any inside information. [7] X Expert Source Lucy Yeh Career & Life Coach Expert Interview. 21 November 2019.

steps.title: Send an email if you have a hiring manager’s contact info.
steps.content: Send an email if you have a hiring manager’s contact info. An email is probably the easiest way to go for a followup question. [8] X Expert Source Lucy Yeh Career & Life Coach Expert Interview. 21 November 2019. You can check the company website or the job application submission criteria for the email of a hiring manager or HR personnel. [9] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Business Review Online and print journal covering topics related to business management practices Go to source

steps.title: Call the company if you feel comfortable doing so.
steps.content: Call the company if you feel comfortable doing so. If you can’t find anyone’s email, giving the company a call is your next best bet. You can try calling an HR person directly, or you can call the main office and ask for a hiring manager. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Ask if your application was received.
steps.content: Ask if your application was received. Just double-check that the company got your resumé and that everything looks good. If there was an error on your end (or their end), you might need to send in your application again. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Inquire about a timeframe for the recruiting process.
steps.content: Inquire about a timeframe for the recruiting process. Don’t be pushy about it, but make sure you sound interested about the job. Say something like, “I was wondering how long it typically takes to fill a role like this.” [12] X Research source

steps.title: See if they need any additional information from you.
steps.content: See if they need any additional information from you. If there was anything missing on your application, they might not have enough info to approve it. Double-check by asking, “Did you need anything else from me before reviewing my application?” After that, you can thank them for their time and end the call or email. [13] X Research source

steps.title: About 1 week after the date they said they’d contact you.
steps.content: About 1 week after the date they said they’d contact you. Interviewers are busy, and they might get a little sidetracked before contacting you again. If 1 week passes after you were supposed to hear back from the company, send an email to the person who interviewed you. [14] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Business Review Online and print journal covering topics related to business management practices Go to source

steps.title: Send an email expressing how you’re still interested.
steps.content: Send an email expressing how you’re still interested. Reiterate how you enjoyed your interview and that you’re eager to hear back about the job. End with a line about how you’re excited about the opportunity. You could try something like: [15] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Business Review Online and print journal covering topics related to business management practices Go to source “Dear Mrs. Harrington, I wanted to follow up about my interview on March 18th for the management position. I really enjoyed our discussion and learning more about the company. Please let me know if there’s any additional information you need from me. I’m very grateful for the opportunity to work at WikiHow. Best, Jeff Rogers.”
